text: (Joff) Andrew Como presented his agenda for the first 100 days of his third term in a recent speech, reiterated a theme from his 2018 re-election campaign, and called New York "The Progressive Capital of the Nation" while the federal government "takes us backwards." Paid family leave was one of the policies that made New York more progressive than other states. "We are the first country to truly attack economic injustice by raising the minimum wage to $15, passing the best paid family leave and free university education programs in the United States of America," We wondered, does New York have the best paid family leave program in the country? The Federal Family and Medical Leave Act provides for unpaid leave of up to 12 weeks for 60 per cent of the workforce. However, according to the Office of Labour Statistics, only 13 per cent of private sector workers in the United States take paid leave through their employers. Four states - New York, New Jersey, Rose Island and California - have active policies for paid family leave, according to the Congressional Research Service. Washington, D.C., Washington, D.C., and Massachusetts enacted programs in 2017 or 2018, which will manage the benefits in 2020 or 2021. Funding, eligibility criteria, duration of benefits and value of benefits vary among states. However, every programme gives leave to the parents of a newly arrived child by birth, adoption or foster care, as well as to care for a close family member who suffers from a serious health condition. New York law is financed by employee contributions through a payroll tax. New York offered eight weeks of paid leave in 2018, up to 10 weeks in 2019 and 2020, and 12 weeks in 2021.
